source_id: STP1245-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_10th Volume_012_chunk1
evidence_span: Three coordinated research programs were undertaken on the fracture toughness of Zr-2.5Nb pressure tubes

source_id: STP1245-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_10th Volume_012_chunk1
evidence_span: a correlation exists between the toughness of the pressure tube material before and after irradiation to a fast-neutron fluence of 1×10^26 n·m^-2 (E > 1 MeV)

source_id: STP1245-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_10th Volume_012_chunk1
evidence_span: for the majority of tubes, degradation occurs early in the lifetime of a CANDU reactor; that is, at fluences < 2×10^24 n·m^-2

source_id: STP1245-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_10th Volume_012_chunk1
evidence_span: saturation is complete by about 1.6×10^25 n·m^-2

source_id: STP1245-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_10th Volume_012_chunk1
evidence_span: in the presence of void nucleating sites, such as microsegregated species (chlorine and carbide) and particles (phosphides and carbides), very large reductions in toughness occur with irradiation

source_id: STP1245-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_10th Volume_012_chunk1
evidence_span: In the absence of such species, there is little deterioration in toughness, and the high crack-tip strains (toughness) achieved with unirradiated material can be maintained after irradiation

source_id: STP1245-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_10th Volume_012_chunk1
evidence_span: The thin-walled pressure tubes in a CANDU reactor are fabricated from cold-worked Zr-2.5Nb and have a length of 6.3 m, inside diameter of 103 mm, and wall thickness of 4.2 mm

evidence_span: The final dual-phase microstructure of a typical Zr-2.5Nb pressure tube consists of a network of elongated α-phase (hexagonal-close-packed), containing about 1% by weight niobium in solution, surrounded by a thin film of β-phase (body-centered-cubic), with about 20% by weight niobium

source_id: STP1245-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_10th Volume_012_chunk6
evidence_span: the results confirm that the major degradation in toughness of $\mathbf { Z } \mathbf { r } { - } 2 . 5 \mathbf { N } \mathbf { b }$ pressure tube material occurs at relatively low fluences $\mathbf { \bar { < } } 2 . 9 \times 1 0 ^ { 2 4 } \mathbf { n } \cdot \mathbf { m } ^ { - 2 }$ , with little further change with increasing irradiation. Saturation appears to be complete by a fast-neutron fluence of about $1 . 6 \times 1 0 ^ { 2 5 } \mathrm { ~ n ~ } \cdot \mathrm { ~ m ~ } ^ { - 2 }$

source_id: STP1245-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_10th Volume_012_chunk6

Saturation appears to be complete by a fast-neutron fluence of about $1 . 6 \times 1 0 ^ { 2 5 } \mathrm { ~ n ~ } \cdot \mathrm { ~ m ~ } ^ { - 2 }$

evidence_span: The variation in toughness of OsIRIS specimens may be partly due to the effects of $\gamma \cdot$ . heating associated with a high-flux facility. $\pmb { \gamma }$ -heating results in a temperature gradient of up to $1 1 \mathrm { ‰}$ between the center and surface of the compact toughness specimens.

source_id: STP1245-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_10th Volume_012_chunk7
evidence_span: A typical fissure intersecting the fatigue crack tip is shown in Fig. 10. The fissure initiates directly from the fatigue crack with no prior crack-tip blunting, indicative of a local zone of low void nucleation strain (toughness).

source_id: STP1245-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_10th Volume_012_chunk7
evidence_span: Such granular zones were frequently observed in all specimens and occasionally developed into fissures in the fracture zone.

source_id: STP1245-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_10th Volume_012_chunk7
evidence_span: In a few cases, deep transverse-axial cracks would be associated with these regions, the room temperature cracks being extended into the high-temperature stable crack growth region and "healing up" along a fissure.

source_id: STP1245-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_10th Volume_012_chunk7
evidence_span: material from the highest toughness tubes, H850 and 230, exhibited large cracktip blunting zones with crack branching, significant through-thickness yield, and a narrow tapered zone of flat fracture at the mid-thickness, Fig. 1la.

source_id: STP1245-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_10th Volume_012_chunk7
evidence_span: There was no evidence of fissure formation, but of equiaxed and tearing dimples of varying size, Fig. 11b.

source_id: STP1245-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_10th Volume_012_chunk7
evidence_span: Compared to the unirradiated specimens, the dimples were generally smaller for the irradiated material, with extremely fine dimples along surface shear lips.

source_id: STP1245-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_10th Volume_012_chunk7
evidence_span: Long deep cracks were also evident in the highly constrained region at the midsection of the irradiated material, Fig. 11a, presumably as a result of the high crack-tip strain in this region.

source_id: STP1245-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_10th Volume_012_chunk7
evidence_span: The difference in toughness of Tubes H850 and 230, Fig. 6, appeared to be related to the extent of multiple crack nucleation (crack branching)

evidence_span: higher toughness specimens exhibiting more crack deviation.

evidence_span: Such material removal from one fracture surface appears to result from deformation and void nucleation along intense shear bands approximately $4 5 ^ { \circ }$ to the axial and transverse directions

source_id: STP1245-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_10th Volume_012_chunk9

evidence_span: It should be noted that the lattice parameter measurements indicated an expansion of the $\pmb { \alpha }$ -phase, even at low fluences $( 5 \times 1 0 ^ { 2 4 } \mathrm { ~ n ~ } \cdot \mathrm { ~ m ~ } ^ { - 2 } )$ consistent with depletion of Nb (Nb being an undersized solute).

evidence_span: chemical microanalysis by energy dispersive $\mathbf { X }$ -ray analysis (EDXA) revealed that iron (an impurity that concentrates in the $\beta$ phase) is dispersed with irradiation, the dispersion increasing with fluence and being complete by $2 . 7 5 \times 1 0 ^ { 2 5 } \mathrm { ~ n ~ } \cdot \mathrm { m } ^ { - 2 }$
